technical_concept: A Large Language Model (LLM) is a neural network with billions of parameters, trained on massive text data. It generates text by predicting the next token (word piece) based on everything before it. It doesn't 'know' things — it recognizes patterns. Models range from 7B parameters (fast, cheap) to 400B+ (powerful, expensive).

code_example.code:
Input: "What is the capital of France?"

Output: "The capital of France is Paris. It is the largest
city in France and serves as the country's political,
economic, and cultural center..."

challenge.task: Ask the LLM anything. Type a question and see a real AI respond. This is a live connection to a real language model.
challenge.hint: Type any question — 'What is quantum computing?', 'Explain Docker in one sentence', 'Write a haiku about Java'. Anything goes!

dialogue.line: Science Officer Chen, report. We've been receiving that signal from the Kepler sector for three days now. What have you found?

Commander, it's not random noise. It's an intelligence. Artificial, but remarkably sophisticated. Billions of parameters — think of them as neural connections. It was trained on vast archives of text from an ancient civilization.

Not like we learn. It consumed enormous amounts of text and learned patterns — which words follow which, in what context. It doesn't know facts. It predicts what comes next. But it does it so well, it appears to understand.

The smallest models have 7 billion parameters. Mid-range: 70 billion. The signal we're receiving? It's coming from something with over 200 billion. We've designated it ARIA — Artificial Reasoning Intelligence Array.

That's what I wanted to show you. We send it a text transmission — a prompt. It processes the signal token by token and generates a response. It doesn't think in words like we do. But the result... see for yourself, Commander.
Then let's make first contact. Open a channel to ARIA.
Team meeting, everyone. HR just informed me we have a new team member starting today. Name's Alex.
Another junior? We just finished onboarding the last one.
Not exactly. Alex is... an AI. A Large Language Model. 200 billion parameters.
Oh great. So it's autocomplete on steroids.
Sam, be nice. It was trained on basically the entire internet. Documents, books, code, conversations—
Which means it learned to sound confident even when it's completely wrong. Just like our last project manager.

The point is, Alex can generate text, answer questions, write code. We just send it a message and it responds. It doesn't actually 'know' things — it predicts the most likely next word. But it's very good at it.
Fine. But I'm setting expectations low. Let's see what the intern can do.
That's the spirit! Go ahead — introduce yourself. Ask Alex anything.
